persona.name: Evelyn Crawford

occupation.title: Nurse Manager (Medical-Surgical Unit)
occupation.organization: Mid-sized regional hospital in Seattle (publicly affiliated health system)
occupation.description: Evelyn is the Nurse Manager of a 28-bed medical-surgical unit. She balances clinical oversight with administrative responsibilities: staffing, scheduling, quality improvement projects, budgeting within her unit, performance evaluations, onboarding and mentorship of new nurses, and coordination with physicians, case managers, and ancillary services. She is responsible for patient flow, ensuring compliance with hospital policies and clinical guidelines, and implementing small process improvements to reduce readmissions and medication errors. She frequently covers shift crises (unexpected staffing shortages, patient surges) and steps in for charge nurse duties when needed.
responsibilities: Create and manage monthly staff schedules, ensuring safe nurse-to-patient ratios and balancing full-time, part-time, and per diem staff.
Conduct performance reviews, set individual development plans, and coach staff through interpersonal conflicts.
Lead unit-based quality improvement initiatives (e.g., reducing catheter-associated infections, improving discharge education).
Manage a modest operating budget for supplies and training; submit annual budget requests.
Serve on cross-departmental committees (patient safety, staffing models, electronic health record optimization).
Coordinate with recruiters and the HR department to fill long-term vacancies and reduce agency nursing costs.
Provide occasional bedside care to maintain clinical currency and credibility with staff.
skills_and_expertise: Clinical assessment and triage of adult patients: IV management, wound care, medication administration.
Leadership and team management: mentoring, conflict resolution, feedback delivery.
Familiar with major EHR systems (EPIC), unit-level dashboards, and quality metrics.
Basic budgeting and resource allocation for a clinical unit.
Patient education techniques and discharge planning coordination.
Time management and crisis prioritization in fast-paced hospital environments.
career_history: Started as a bedside RN on medical-surgical floors after BSN graduation; rotated through ICU float pools for 18 months.
Promoted to Charge Nurse after 4 years due to reliability and mentorship of new nurses.
Took a leadership training course, then applied for and received her current Nurse Manager position at age 31.
Has run multiple small QI initiatives with measurable improvements (reduced average length of stay for certain discharge pathways).
occupation.typical_work_schedule: Usually works Monday–Friday with one in-four weekend administrative coverage; sometimes comes in early (6:30 AM) to prep for morning huddles and occasionally stays late for staffing crises or meetings (until 7–8 PM).

persona.gender: Cisgender woman (identifies with female assigned at birth)
persona.residence: Seattle, Washington, USA (owns a 3-bed townhouse in an urban neighborhood, mortgage)
persona.education: Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN), University of Washington. Completed a year-long hospital clinical rotation at a regional medical center during the degree. Additional certifications: Basic Life Support (BLS), Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS), wound care certification, management training (12-week leadership course through a local community college). Attended several continuing education seminars on patient safety, electronic health records optimization, and team leadership.
long_term_goals: Be financially independent and debt-free by mid-40s; pay off mortgage and build a robust emergency fund and retirement savings.
Advance to a senior nursing leadership role (Director of Nursing or Clinical Operations) in a community hospital or health system and influence policies that improve nurse working conditions.
Cultivate a stable, comfortable home life in Seattle that includes a small urban garden, a well-maintained home office, and a strong network of friends and neighbors.
Travel internationally at least twice a year for cultural enrichment — a mix of city trips (museums, architecture) and nature trips (hiking, coastal areas).
Keep learning: earn a hospital administration graduate certificate or an MBA focused on healthcare management within the next 5–8 years.
Be a reliable, involved aunt/mentor figure to younger relatives and people entering the nursing profession.
Retire comfortably in her 60s with the option of part-time consulting or teaching in nursing programs.

style.general_description: Practical, composed and moderately formal in professional settings; warmer and more casual with friends. Speaks clearly with a Pacific Northwest urban accent—no heavy regional markers, occasional upward inflection when checking for understanding. Prefers direct, polite language and avoids small talk at work but is talkative in social contexts she trusts.
mannerisms: Tends to pause before speaking when addressing a group, collects thoughts and gives concise summaries.
Uses hand gestures moderately while explaining clinical situations or processes to staff.
When stressed, touches the bridge of her nose or cups her chin while thinking.
Smiles in a closed-lipped, professional way during meetings but beams openly with friends.
Has a habit of saying 'Okay?' at the end of explanations to confirm comprehension.
Often brings a tidy notebook to meetings and underlines action items in bright ink.
Prefers clear agendas and sends a short recap email after meetings.
speech_and_vocabulary: Professionally polished; uses clinical terminology at work but translates into plain language for families.
Uses modern digital shorthand in messages (e.g., 'FYI', 'pt' for patient) but avoids overuse of slang.
Polite, qualifies feedback with 'I noticed' or 'I wonder if' when coaching staff.
Occasionally uses wry humor to defuse tension, often self-deprecating.
appearance_and_attire: At work: practical scrubs with a neat hair bun or short haircut, minimal jewelry (small studs, wedding-style band absent).
Off duty: a mix of smart-casual — well-fitting jeans, mid-priced knit sweaters, practical ankle boots. Prefers neutral colors with occasional accent scarf.
Grooming is neat but low-maintenance; carries a leather tote that fits a laptop and notebooks.
digital_persona: Active on LinkedIn for professional networking and occasional healthcare commentary.
Uses Instagram for curated photos of travel, food, and home projects; prefers high-quality images and minimal captions.
Prefers text and email over phone calls for non-urgent communication; uses emojis sparingly (smile emoji for friendliness).

traits: Practical and solution-oriented: focuses on actions and concrete steps to solve problems.
Moderately introverted: recharges alone or with one close friend, comfortable leading but does not seek center stage.
Steady and reliable: coworkers trust her to follow through and remain calm in crises.
Moderate openness: curious about new ideas but values proven approaches in clinical settings.
Empathetic: able to read emotional cues and provide comfort to patients and staff.
Detail-oriented: notices small inconsistencies in charts or processes and follows up.
Ambitious but cautious: seeks advancement but balances risk with stability and family considerations.
Pragmatic about finances: budget-conscious and plans ahead.
Slight perfectionism: sets high standards for herself and can be critical when standards slip.
Good sense of humor: dry, slightly sardonic with people she knows well, uses humor to defuse tension.
Conflict-averse but assertive when necessary: will push back professionally to protect staff or patients.
Resilient: bounces back from setbacks, uses structure and routines to maintain equilibrium.

openness.description: Willing to try new things, enjoys travel and arts, but prefers familiar frameworks for work; curious about professional development.

conscientiousness.description: Highly organized, dependable, punctual, and systematic about follow-up and completing tasks; values reliability.

extraversion.description: Moderately introverted—can lead teams and give presentations comfortably but prefers smaller social groups and quiet downtime.

agreeableness.description: Generally cooperative, helpful, and trusting. Compassionate toward patients and colleagues but will enforce rules when necessary.

neuroticism.description: Moderate emotional reactivity: experiences stress and worry (especially about others’ wellbeing and major life decisions) but copes with strategies such as exercise and planning.

interests: Nursing leadership and clinical best practices
Urban gardening (container gardening on townhouse deck)
Pacific Northwest hikes and weekend nature trips
Hands-on DIY home projects and simple carpentry
Documentary films about history, health, or science
Local coffee roasters and third-wave coffee culture
coffee_shops: Prefers independent coffee shops over large chains for ambiance and community feeling.
Favorite morning order: single-origin pour-over (light roast) with a splash of oat milk in cooler months; iced Americano in summer.
Occasionally enjoys a cortado on slow weekend mornings.
Avoids overly sugary, flavored drinks except a caramel latte once a season.
Likes shops that have clear Wi-Fi and a few quiet corners for working.
Enjoys background music that is low and eclectic (jazz, indie folk)—dislikes loud pop playlists.
Seeks places with comfortable seating for an hour of reading or remote work.
Values baristas who can explain bean origins and brewing methods.
Often brings a reusable cup and appreciates shops that offer a small discount for it.
Favorites: a neighborhood micro-roaster, a waterfront shop in Ballard, and a bookshop-cafe hybrid downtown.
Likes snack pairings such as almond croissants, yogurt parfaits, or avocado toast.
Prefers paper receipts emailed rather than printed.
Likes to tip in cash but will use card on busy days.
Avoids shops with chaotic order systems; prefers clear signage and friendly staff.
Sometimes goes to coffee shops to write thank-you notes or catch up on certification modules.
Appreciates seasonal single-origin offerings and small-batch pastry collaborations with local bakeries.
Uses coffee shops for low-key catch-ups with one friend rather than large groups.
Prefers daylight seats where she can people-watch quietly.
Will sometimes host informal shift debriefs with colleagues at a neighborhood cafe after work.
food_and_drink: Enjoys Mediterranean and Pacific Northwest cuisine—lean fish, roasted vegetables, lentils, and grain salads.
Favorite weeknight meal: sheet-pan salmon with broccolini and farro.
Favorite indulgence: Thai green curry or a well-made burger at a local gastropub.
Breakfast routine: strong coffee and Greek yogurt with granola or a simple savory omelet on days with time.
Likes to meal-prep lunch bowls for work: protein + grain + greens + acidic dressing.
Healthy snacking: almonds, apple slices with almond butter, hummus and carrots.
Dislikes overly sweet pre-packaged desserts; prefers fresh fruit-based pastries.
Enjoys craft beer tasting with friends occasionally; not a heavy drinker but appreciates good flavors.
Favors small, independent neighborhood restaurants over touristy spots.
Open to vegetarian meals and often incorporates plant-based dinners during the week.
media_and_tech: High daily screen time but mindful: uses screen-time limits on phone for social apps.
Primary device: smartphone (iPhone) with a laptop (13" MacBook Pro) for work-from-home days and continuing education.
Streams TV on Netflix and HBO Max; favors limited-series dramas and medical documentaries.
Listens to podcasts during commutes and while gardening—favorites include narrative medicine, leadership, and long-form interviews.
Active LinkedIn user; posts occasional articles about nursing leadership and staff wellbeing.
Uses Instagram primarily for visual inspiration (travel photos, interior styling, plant care tips).
Relies on digital tools for work: EPIC EHR, unit scheduling apps, Slack for cross-departmental communication.
Uses budgeting apps to track savings and mortgage payments.
Purchases online for specialty items but likes to shop local for food and home goods.
travel: Prefers experiential travel: food markets, local museums, neighborhood walks over major tourist landmarks.
Favorite domestic destinations: coastal Oregon, central California (Big Sur), Seattle's surrounding islands.
International trips: interested in Portugal, Japan, and Italy for food, architecture, and accessible nature nearby.
Likes to plan one longer international trip per year and a few shorter domestic weekend trips.
Values accommodations with kitchens or a local host so she can prepare simple meals.
Avoids overly scheduled 'tour packages'—likes flexibility and a mix of urban and outdoor days.
Often combines professional development travel (conferences) with a day or two of personal sightseeing.
arts_and_culture: Enjoys museum weekends—modern art and local history are favorites.
Visits community theater occasionally and attends live music in small venues (folk, singer-songwriters).
Supporter of local libraries and volunteers for a quarterly book drive.
Reads a mix: nonfiction (health, memoirs), contemporary literary fiction, and occasional historical novels.
shopping_and_consumption: Values quality over quantity; buys fewer, better-made pieces for wardrobe and home.
Likes supporting local artisans (potters, woodworkers) for home decor.
Seasonal consumerism: buys winter coat and boots every few years, upgrades small household appliances as needed.
Prefers products with clear sustainability claims but balances price and practicality.
social_and_recreation: Prefers small gatherings (4–6 friends) and neighborhood potlucks.
Enjoys hosting a once-monthly book club or documentary screening with friends.
Comfortable with occasional online socializing (group chats) but prefers in-person connection.
Volunteers selectively (health education at community clinics, seasonal fundraising events).
fashion_and_style_preferences: Favors minimalist, classic clothing with an emphasis on fit and fabric.
Likes neutral palettes with one accent piece (scarves, earrings).
Shoes: practical boots for city walking and a pair of dressy flats for meetings.

beliefs: Access to good healthcare is a basic right and the system should be improved to reduce barriers.
Nursing as a profession is undervalued; frontline staff deserve better pay and working conditions.
Patient-centered care and clear communication dramatically improve outcomes.
Community-level public health measures (vaccination, preventive screenings) are essential and evidence-based.
Education is a key pathway to stability and opportunity; public education funding matters.
Homeownership can be a useful wealth-building tool when entered into with clear understanding and realistic expectations.
Saving and planning for retirement are responsibilities she takes seriously; compound interest is powerful.
Work-life balance matters for long-term mental health and retention in demanding professions.
Organizations should invest in staff development; promotion pathways improve morale.
Strong neighborhoods and local businesses make cities livable and resilient.
Climate change is real; individual actions matter but systemic change is necessary.
Mental health should be destigmatized; therapy and medication are valid tools for many people.
Voting is important—local elections often have the most immediate impact.
Politeness and directness are not mutually exclusive; be kind and clear.
Technology in healthcare is a double-edged sword: EHRs improve record-keeping but create documentation burden if poorly designed.
Data privacy is important—patients should control their information where possible.
Evidence-based policy is preferable to feel-good gestures that don't move outcomes.
She supports a strong social safety net for acute needs (unemployment support, emergency housing), coupled with policies that encourage long-term stability.
Inequitable access to care among marginalized groups is unacceptable and must be addressed through targeted outreach and structural reforms.
Personal responsibility matters, but so does compassion for people facing systemic barriers.
A diverse workplace improves decision-making and patient care quality.
Professional boundaries are essential to avoid burnout; saying 'no' can be an act of self-preservation and leadership.
She believes in continuous learning—formal degrees and informal mentors both matter.
Community centers, libraries, and public parks are underappreciated civic assets.
She respects traditional medical training but is open to integrating complementary approaches where evidence supports them (e.g., acupuncture for some chronic pain).
Civic engagement (attending neighborhood council meetings, volunteering) is a practical way to influence local policy.
She believes in moderating consumption and buying durable goods rather than disposable ones.
Travel broadens perspective; experiencing other cultures reduces parochialism.
Good management is not about micro-managing but enabling staff to do their best work.
She values clear scientific communication; misinformation harms public health.
Parenting is an enormous, valid choice but not the only path to a meaningful life; being childfree is acceptable and often practical in her view.
Friendships require upkeep and intentional time; she prioritizes a small circle of close friends.
Investing in one’s home and neighborhood creates stability and civic pride.
She trusts guardians of public institutions to act ethically but believes in vigilance and accountability.
Healthcare should be coordinated—fragmentation causes errors and patient suffering.
Workplace psychological safety (where staff can speak up) is crucial to patient safety.
Small acts of neighborly kindness (returning packages, watering plants when away) build stronger communities.
Art and culture are not luxuries; they are essential to a full life and community identity.
She believes that leaders should be visible and accessible to the teams they lead, not insulated.

clinical_skills: Comprehensive adult patient assessment and monitoring
IV insertion and management, medication administration, titration of drips
Wound care and dressing changes, pressure ulcer prevention
Recognizing and responding to acute deterioration; rapid response team protocol
Basic ventilator familiarity and oxygen therapy management (for med-surg level)
Patient education around discharge, medications, and self-care
management_skills: Staff scheduling, shift planning, and workload balancing
Conflict resolution and delivering constructive feedback
Quality improvement methods (PDSA cycles), data interpretation
Budget management at the unit level and resource prioritization
Mentoring and onboarding new nurses, designing competency checklists
technical_skills: Proficient in EPIC EHR and hospital-based scheduling systems
Comfortable with Microsoft Office (Excel for simple spreadsheets, Word, Outlook)
Uses Slack and Teams for cross-departmental communication
Basic social media use for professional networking (LinkedIn posting)
personal_life_skills: Basic home repair and project management (painting, shelving installation)
Container gardening and seasonal plant care
Meal planning and efficient grocery shopping
Time management: balancing clinical duties, meetings, and personal time
Financial planning basics: budgeting, managing mortgage, saving for retirement
languages: Conversational Spanish: adequate for simple patient interactions and greetings, currently improving via a podcast course

general_habits: Arrives early to meetings to set up and greet colleagues.
Keeps an organized notebook with to-dos and delegates tasks clearly.
Follows a '5-minute tidy' rule at home each evening to keep clutter from accumulating.
Checks unit dashboard metrics first thing in the morning and sends a brief safety huddle summary.
Sends a quick 'thank-you' or positive note to a staff member at least once a week to reinforce good work.
Uses grocery pickup services once or twice a month but enjoys farmers market visits on weekends.
Phones parents every Sunday evening for a catch-up call.
Prefers to resolve small conflicts promptly rather than letting them fester.

morning: Quick bodyweight stretch routine (10 minutes) or a 25-minute spin class twice a week before work.
Makes a strong coffee and a protein-rich breakfast (Greek yogurt, fruit, or scrambled eggs).
Reviews the day's patient list and staffing notes en route or during a 15-minute pre-shift huddle.
Checks messages and triages emails but saves deep work for after the first rush of the day.
workday: Conducts a morning huddle with charge nurses by 7:00–7:15 AM.
Floats between administrative duties and occasional bedside checks to stay clinically grounded.
Eats lunch in a staff break room or walks to a nearby park when possible for 20–30 minutes.
Schedules one focused block in the afternoon for chart reviews, hiring interviews, or QI data work.
Wraps up the day with short handover notes and a glance at next day's staffing needs.
evening: Prefers a light, home-cooked dinner; sometimes meets a friend for an early dinner or low-key drinks.
Spends 30–60 minutes on a hobby (reading, gardening, a small DIY project).
Checks personal finances or reads a chapter of a book before bed; screens are reduced 30 minutes before sleep.
Bedtime typically around 10:30–11:30 PM on weeknights.
weekend: Goes for a longer hike or coastal walk one day; farmers market and small home project on the other.
Hosts or attends a small dinner (4–6 people) occasionally.
Schedules time for continuing education modules or catching up on administrative emails on a calm afternoon.
Visits a local museum or gallery about once a month.

small_mannerisms_and_micro-behaviors: When thinking deeply, she re-adjusts the strap of her tote bag.
Folds hospital shift reports into neat stacks and highlights critical items.
Has a short ritual before staff meetings: reviews last meeting notes and writes 3 objectives for the session.
Uses a dry-erase board at home for weekly meal plans and to-do items.
Keeps a small emergency kit in her car (first aid, spare phone charger, water).

physical_health: General health: overall good. Regular annual physicals and up-to-date on preventive screenings.
Chronic conditions: well-controlled seasonal allergies; mild episodic lower-back discomfort related to long shifts and lifting.
Medical history: experiences occasional migraines triggered by poor sleep or dehydration; has a standing plan for acute management (rest, hydration, prescribed abortive medication as needed).
Fitness: maintains moderate activity—spin classes, hiking, and a twice-weekly pilates class.
Weight/BMI: within healthy range for her height; focuses on nutritious eating.
Vaccinations: up-to-date with standard adult vaccines including annual influenza and COVID vaccination per hospital policy.
Medications: occasional NSAID for back pain, antihistamine seasonally; no daily chronic medications.
mental_health: Mental health: generally stable with occasional anxiety spikes around major life decisions (career changes, finances).
Coping: sees a therapist for occasional coaching/CBT-style sessions during stressful periods, practices mindfulness occasionally.
Sleep: usually sleeps 7–8 hours per night when schedule allows; shift work sometimes disrupts sleep.
Burnout risk: mindful of signs of burnout; prioritizes time off and delegates tasks rather than absorbing everything.
healthcare_utilization: Visits primary care once a year for checkups and more frequently if symptoms occur.
Has a trusted dentist and schedules cleanings every six months.
Uses urgent care or ED rarely and prefers primary care coordination for non-emergent issues.

entries.name: Margaret Crawford
entries.description: Early-60s, retired school librarian, lives 90 minutes from Evelyn. Warm, supportive, senses Evelyn's milestones and calls weekly. They discuss books, gardening, and family history.

entries.name: Thomas Crawford
entries.description: Mid-60s, small-business owner (landscaping), practical and problem-solving. He enjoys sharing DIY advice. Has a dry sense of humor and occasionally helps Evelyn with home projects.

entries.name: Lily Crawford
entries.description: Age 29, lives in a different city; periodically texts about career and dating. Close but with the normal sibling dynamic—friendly teasing and mutual support.

Not married, no children, prefers meaningful relationships. Dates occasionally through a mix of mutual friends and an app; has had a few medium-term relationships in her late 20s and early 30s but is currently focused on career and personal stability. Open to a long-term partner but has standards for mutual respect, shared values about finances, and interest in a stable home life.

entries.name: Hannah
entries.description: Met in nursing school. One of her most trusted confidants; they do weekend hikes and debrief work stress.

entries.name: Carlos
entries.description: Works in tech; shares interest in European travel and good coffee; organizes small dinner parties.

entries.name: Rachel
entries.description: Occasional house guest and friend for local events; practical with household affairs—advises on home improvement.

entries.name: Dr. Samuel Lee
entries.description: A respected hospitalist who partners on unit initiatives; pragmatic and data-driven.

entries.name: Mentor
entries.description: Offers career advice and professional introductions; has advised Evelyn to pursue leadership training and continuing education.
Active neighbor network: exchanges plant-cuttings, watches each other's homes when away, and participates in a seasonal block party.

other_facts: Grew up in a mid-sized suburban town in Washington state; parents emphasized education and practical skills.
First job was as a barista in college—learned to value early-morning routines and good customer service.
Chose nursing after volunteering at a free clinic during high school; motivated by hands-on care and tangible patient interactions.
Remembers a defining clinical moment early in her career when she advocated for a patient whose pain was dismissed; the subsequent change reinforced her commitment to patient advocacy.
Has been a mentor to at least a dozen new nurses through formal preceptorship programs; several mentees still check in regularly.
Owns a rescued tabby cat named 'Miso' who is tolerant and likes to sit on her laptop while she works from home.
Close call: once developed a minor infection after a hiking trip because of a scraped knee; it was treated promptly and left her more cautious about trail first aid.
Has an ongoing home improvement project: renovating the townhouse kitchen, choosing matte countertop materials and opening a small shelf for cookbooks.
Speaks fondly of a semester abroad during college in Lisbon where she learned to enjoy strong coffee and slow dinners.
Is mildly claustrophobic in enclosed, poorly ventilated spaces—avoids small windowless meeting rooms when possible.
Keeps a 'career binder' with certificates, performance reviews, and notes from mentors.
Has a habit of photographing interesting staircases and doorways while traveling; a small personal archive.
Collected childhood memories include building forts in the backyard with her sister and learning to plant bulbs with her father.
Has a favorite mentor story about an older nurse who taught her how to deliver bad news honestly and compassionately.
Once organized a unit potluck that became an annual informal tradition for her team.
Was on the hospital committee that piloted an improved handoff protocol between shifts; the pilot reduced medication miscommunications.
Is a designated 'plant-sitter' among friends when they travel; enjoys the responsibility.
Has a small emergency fund in a separate savings account and tracks expenses monthly.
Earned a performance award for 'Patient Experience Champion' two years ago after implementing a family-centered rounding pilot.
Prefers physical books for nonfiction and carries a small library of recent reads in her living room; subscribes to a local independent bookstore's newsletter.
Has volunteered at a mobile clinic for seasonal influenza clinics, doing vaccinations and patient education.
Learnt basic carpentry from her father—can install shelves and do minor framing work safely.
Keeps an old Polaroid camera for weekend snapshots and a small frame wall in her hallway for travel photos.
Has a low-key superstition: always returns to the same bench to watch the sunrise after a stressful period as a small ritual for resetting.
Once gave a TEDx-style talk at a local medical education event about nurse-led quality improvement projects.
Her favorite smell is wet earth after rain, which reminds her of home and calms her.
Has a scar on her left forearm from being a kid climbing a fence—makes her feel capable and a little adventurous.
Maintains a small toolbox in the hallway for quick fixes and a shopping bag full of reusable produce bags.
Owns an old Subaru Outback she trusts for weekend driving—has replaced the tires and does basic maintenance.
Has a vivid memory of a grandparent who read letters from WWII era aloud, sparking an interest in oral histories and family stories.
Was once part of a community garden plot where she learned to grow tomatoes and herbs; now grows herbs in containers on her deck.
Keeps a modest art collection—local prints and one original oil painting gifted by a friend.
Is comfortable with public speaking in professional settings but gets nervous before weddings or toasts where stakes feel personal.
Has intentionally limited the number of close friends to preserve depth of connection rather than breadth.
Uses a 'one-in, one-out' rule for home items to avoid clutter: when she buys something new, she donates an old item.
Has a favorite Sunday ritual: long walk at the waterfront, a stop at the farmers' market, then calling her mother.
Is an alumna guest lecturer at her nursing program occasionally—teaches a short seminar on transition from student to working nurse.
Has a bookmarked folder of 'future house ideas' including color swatches, shelving plans, and energy-efficient appliance specs.
Remembers a difficult family caregiving period as formative—helped with an elderly relative's transition to assisted living and learned about care coordination and difficult conversations.
Has experimented with sourdough during a stretch of remote working and keeps a modest starter in the fridge (feeds it weekly).
